title: Paul Before the Council
shortSummary: Acts 23 recounts Paul's bold defense before the Jewish council, highlighting the division between Pharisees and Sadducees over the resurrection. Despite threats on his life, God assures Paul of His presence and future mission, leading to Paul's transfer to Governor Felix for a fair trial.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Imprisonment in Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle on trial, boldly proclaiming his faith and navigating threats against his life.

keyCharacters.name: Ananias
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who orders Paul to be struck, provoking Paul's sharp rebuke.

keyCharacters.name: Claudius Lysias
keyCharacters.description: The Roman chief captain who rescues Paul from a Jewish plot and arranges his transfer to Felix.

keyCharacters.name: Felix
keyCharacters.description: The Roman governor in Caesarea who receives Paul and orders him to be kept in custody.

definitions.definition: A Jewish sect known for strict adherence to the Law and belief in the resurrection of the dead.
A Jewish sect that denied the resurrection, angels, and spirits, often opposing the Pharisees.
The chief religious leader in Judaism, responsible for temple worship and legal judgments.
A Roman army officer in charge of approximately one hundred soldiers.

outline.heading: Paul's Defense and Conflict with the High Priest
outline.description: Paul boldly declares his clear conscience before God, but is struck by the high priest, leading Paul to rebuke him and reveal ignorance of his identity, emphasizing respect for authority.

outline.heading: Division Between Pharisees and Sadducees
outline.description: Paul strategically identifies himself as a Pharisee, causing a sharp division in the council over the resurrection, which protects him from immediate harm.

outline.heading: God's Encouragement and Jewish Conspiracy
outline.description: God reassures Paul of his mission to witness in Rome, while a deadly plot by more than forty Jews to kill Paul is revealed.

outline.heading: Paul's Nephew Warns the Authorities
outline.description: Paul's sister's son informs the Roman authorities of the assassination plot, prompting protective measures.

outline.heading: Paul's Transfer to Caesarea
outline.description: Claudius Lysias organizes a large military escort to safely transfer Paul to Governor Felix, who orders Paul to be kept in custody pending a hearing.

application: Stand firm in your faith and conscience even when facing opposition or injustice.
Trust in God's presence and encouragement during times of trial and uncertainty.
Be alert to dangers and seek wise counsel and protection when necessary.
Respect authority while boldly proclaiming the truth of the gospel.

keyVerses.text: And the night following the Lord stood by him, and said, Be of good cheer, Paul: for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witness also at Rome.
keyVerses.significance: God's personal encouragement assures Paul of His presence and the continuation of his mission despite hardships.

keyVerses.text: But when Paul perceived that the one part were Sadducees, and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, Men and brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee: of the hope and resurrection of the dead I am called in question.
keyVerses.significance: Paul wisely uses theological divisions to protect himself and advance the gospel message.

keyVerses.text: Whom I perceived to be accused of questions of their law, but to have nothing laid to his charge worthy of death or of bonds.
keyVerses.significance: Paul's innocence under Roman law is affirmed, highlighting the unjust nature of the accusations against him.
